### What is an IP Address?
An **IP address** (Internet Protocol address) is the unique identifier that every device needs to communicate on a network — think of it as your device's phone number on the internet.

| Version   | Format Example                  | Total Possible Addresses       | Status Today          |
|-----------|---------------------------------|--------------------------------|-----------------------|
| IPv4      | `192.168.10.55`                 | ~4.3 billion                   | Completely exhausted  |
| IPv6      | `2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334` | ~340 undecillion       | Future-proof & growing|

Without an IP, your laptop, phone, or IoT toaster literally cannot send or receive data. Want to know the difference between public and private IPs next?

### IPv4 vs IPv6 – Side-by-Side Comparison
| Feature                  | IPv4                              | IPv6                                   |
|--------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------------------------------|
| Address Length           | 32 bits                           | 128 bits                               |
| Number of Addresses      | ~4.3 billion                      | 340 undecillion (3.4×10³⁸)             |
| Example Address          | `172.16.254.1`                    | `2001:db8:3333:4444:5555:6666:7777:8888` |
| Notation                 | Dotted decimal                    | Colon-separated hexadecimal            |
| NAT Requirement          | Almost always needed              | Not required (end-to-end connectivity) |
| Built-in Security        | IPsec optional                    | IPsec mandatory                        |
| Header Size              | 20–60 bytes                       | Fixed 40 bytes                         |
| Configuration            | Often manual or DHCP              | Auto-config (SLAAC) + DHCPv6           |

**Bottom line**: IPv4 is dead in terms of new addresses. IPv6 is the present and the future.

### Public IP vs Private IP – Quick Table
| Type         | Routable on Internet? | Range Example               | Who Assigns It?         | Typical Use Case                      |
|--------------|------------------------|-----------------------------|-------------------------|----------------------------------------|
| Public IP    | Yes                    | `203.0.113.45`              | ISP / Regional Registry | Web servers, home router WAN side     |
| Private IP   | No                     | `192.168.1.100`, `10.0.0.5` | Your router (NAT)       | Devices inside your home/office LAN   |

**Private IP ranges (RFC 1918)**  
- `10.0.0.0 – 10.255.255.255` (16.7 million devices)  
- `172.16.0.0 – 172.31.255.255`  
- `192.168.0.0 – 192.168.255.255` (most home routers)

Your phone right now probably has a private IP, and your router translates it to a single public IP using NAT.

### Network Address Translation (NAT) Explained
NAT is the magic that lets hundreds of devices share **one** public IP.

| NAT Type         | Description                                               | Common Use                          |
|------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------|
| One-to-One NAT   | One private IP → one public IP                            | Servers, static mappings            |
| PAT (Overload)   | Many private IPs → one public IP using different ports    | Almost every home router            |
| Destination NAT  | Changes destination IP (port forwarding)                  | Gaming, remote desktop              |
| Source NAT       | Changes source IP when leaving the network                | Standard internet access            |

**Example PAT table on your router right now:**
```text
Private IP       Port → Public IP:Port
192.168.1.10:54321 → 203.0.113.1:54321
192.168.1.57:12345 → 203.0.113.1:12345
```
Without NAT, the internet would have died years ago.

### APIPA – Automatic Private IP Addressing
When your device asks for a DHCP address and gets no reply, Windows (and some others) assign themselves an APIPA address.

**APIPA range**: `169.254.0.1 – 169.254.255.254` (subnet mask 255.255.0.0)

| Situation                     | Result                              |
|-------------------------------|-------------------------------------|
| DHCP server down              | Device grabs 169.254.x.y            |
| Cable unplugged               | Same → you see “Limited connectivity” |
| DHCP comes back online        | Device releases APIPA, gets real IP |

It lets devices talk locally even without a proper network — super useful for troubleshooting.

### How to Find Your IP – All Platforms
| Platform       | Command / Method                                          | Example Output                                 |
|----------------|-----------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------|
| Windows        | `ipconfig` in CMD                                         | IPv4: 192.168.1.100                            |
| macOS / Linux  | `ifconfig` or `ip addr show`                              | inet 192.168.1.100/24                          |
| Public IP      | Visit [https://ifconfig.me](https://ifconfig.me) or `curl ifconfig.me` | 85.24.23.112                                   |
| Android        | Settings → About phone → Status                           | 192.168.1.55                                   |
| iPhone         | Settings → Wi-Fi → ⓘ next to network                      | 192.168.1.77                                   |

Your **private** IP is what your router sees. Your **public** IP is what the world sees.

### Loopback IP – Talking to Yourself
The loopback address lets a device send traffic to itself for testing.

| Version | Loopback Range           | Most Common Single Address |
|---------|--------------------------|----------------------------|
| IPv4    | 127.0.0.0 – 127.255.255.255 | 127.0.0.1                |
| IPv6    | ::1                      | ::1                        |

**Fun fact**: `ping 127.0.0.1` or `ping ::1` will always work (as long as TCP/IP stack is loaded) — even with no network cable plugged in.

It’s how developers test software locally.
